subject: Re: [junit] Testing SQL select statements for semantic equivalency

messageBody:
On Sun, Jul 20, 2003 at 10:48:16PM -0400, Jeff Nielsen wrote:

> I'd be interested in people's thoughts on the easiest/best way to do
> this. Basically, we have a bunch of JUnit tests that check SQL
> "SELECT" statements that are generated by a framework.
>
> These tests are currently a little painful to maintain, because if you
> modify the framework so that the order of the tables, columns, or where
> clause statements changes somehow, every test has to change. That got
> me wondering about how to do an
>
> assertSemanticEquals(expectedSQL, actualSQL)
>
> where the order of things within each brance of the select is
> irrelevant. For example,
>
> select foo.col1, bar.col2
> from bar, foo
> where bar.id = foo.id and bar.id > 4
> order by bar.col2
>
> is semantically equivalent to
>
> select bar.col2, foo.col1
> from foo, bar
> where bar.id > 4 and foo.id = bar.id
> order by bar.col2

My colleague and I are working on a research project that is
tangentially related to this question, so I thought that I would
provide a few pointers and see if the JUnit community has some
comments or insights.

We are focusing on the testing and analysis of database-driven
applications by testing the program, the database, and the program's
interaction with the database. Our initial work has focused on the
creation of algorithms that can produce a representation of a program
and its interaction with a database and then enumerate the
database-interaction associations for a new family of data flow-based
test adequacy criteria.

Our initial goal is to determine how well tests ensure that the
program does not violate the completeness and validity of the database
that it defines and uses with embedded SQL statements. In the future,
we will be developing testing tools that aid test data generation,
test execution, and regression testing. Since I frequently use tools
like JUnit, DBUnit, etc. for my own development, my personal goal is
to construct a complete tool suite, based upon these existing tools,
to handle many of these issues.

More information about the Database drIven Application Testing tOol
ModuleS! (DIATOMS) research is available at the following URL:

http://cs.allegheny.edu/~gkapfham/research/diatoms/

My colleague and I would certainly value your comments on our FSE 2003
paper. We also value your insights about some of the practical testing
issues that you would encounter during the application of such test
adequacy criteria and/or other issues related to testing database-driven
applications.

Kind Regards,

greg
